g.text: ) are compiled in Fig. 7, with an emphasis on
recent developments. Over time, early assessments of contrail RF
rmed and the large range of uncertainty
Until 2011, a best central estimate of RF due to contrail cirrus
including RF due to persistent contrails was not available. This
caused large uncertainty in aviation RF as a whole. After IPCC
1999, AIC RF estimates have been based on associating air traf
with regional trends in cirrus coverage without proof of causality
At the top of the atmosphere, annually and globally averaged, incoming shortwave (SW, solar) radiation and the outgoing longwave (LW, thermal)
radiation cancel out unless a climate forcing, such as changes in properties of clouds, perturbs this balance
. An initial perturbation of the radiation
rst-order indicator of the importance of different climate change mechanisms. RF refers to initial imbalances over a speci
region and period of time; those provided by the IPCC
are global averages taken relative to a pre-industrial time (1750). Global RF cannot be observed
directly and is therefore obtained with the help of models or by extrapolation of regional values inferred from satellite observations.
measuring the opacity of a medium when electromagnetic radiation of a given wavelength,
is a crucial determinant of RF. OD
and RF are determined by a number of radiative transfer processes. Ice in high level clouds, i.e., thin cirrus and long-lived contrails, acts similar to cloud-
): it decreases the energy lost to outer space, enhancing the temperature in the atmosphere below the cloud and at the Earth
greenhouse forcing). Cloud ice crystals affect RF by reducing thermal emission (radiant energy with
m) to space via absorption and re-emission
of LW radiation at cold temperatures. Contrary to low clouds composed mainly of liquid water droplets (
), high ice clouds are often optically thin (
i.e., partially transparent to solar radiation (
m), meaning their ability to scatter SW radiation back to space (albedo forcing) is small. The
greenhouse forcing is stronger for higher and colder clouds, in which ice crystals are increasingly abundant. The net average diurnal RF due to thin cirrus
and contrails is a small positive residual from the wavelength-integrated SW and LW forcings. RF contributions due to thickening of natural cirrus by
embedded contrails and new ice crystal formation in contrail areas with low ice crystal concentrations, blurring the distinction between natural cirrus
and contrail cirrus, have not yet been determined.
Solar and thermal radiation close to balance
Ice crystal sizes are smaller in contrails relative to natural
Increased optical thickness of thin natural cirrus with
New ice crystals can form in aging contrails and contrail cirrus
Beside the power received from the Sun (solar irradiance) and Earth
s atmosphere, Earth surface conditions and vertical distribution (overlap) of clouds,
wavelength dependent scattering and absorption properties of single ice crystals are needed to estimate OD and RF. Those properties depend on
shapes (habits), surface roughness and orientation against incident light of cloud ice crystals across their size distribution, all of which are dif
quantify in airborne measurements. Emissivity (absorption and emission at near infrared wavelengths, LW forcing) and re
wavelengths, SW forcing) of high ice clouds are determined by OD and physical properties of ice crystals. Re
ectance is sensitive to the habits of small
ice crystals. Optical contrail models assume mixtures of various habits with
, but exactly which habits prevail and
how individual habits vary with contrail age and ice crystal size is not well known.
Positive (negative) RF induces a warming (cooling) tendency that is subsequently communicated throughout the whole atmosphere. The strength of the
resulting response in globally averaged, equilibrium near surface air temperature,
, is estimated by the climate sensitivity parameter
Values of this parameter and the associated equilibration times depend on the nature, spatial pattern and temporal evolution of RF and on the heat
